content:
Jews have lived in Sokolów Malopolski for many centuries, and the town had a significant Jewish population before World War II. The exact date of the arrival of Jews in the town is not known, but it is believed to date back to at least the 16th century. During this period, Jews were attracted to the town by its location on several important trade routes and its status as a center of commerce and industry.

By the 18th century, the Jewish community in Sokolów Malopolski had grown significantly, and Jews played an important role in the town's economy and cultural life. They were involved in trade, crafts, and industry, and many were active in the town's schools and religious institutions.

During World War II, the Jewish population of Sokolów Malopolski was targeted by the Nazis and most were killed or forced to flee. Today, there are few Jews living in the town, but efforts have been made to preserve the memory of the Jewish community and its history in Sokolów Malopolski.
